texts.definition: Exploratory actions done to learn the rules or state of a game, or to practice one's skills or strategies.
markups: <style="Definition">Exploratory actions done to learn the rules or state of a game, or to practice one's skills or strategies.</style>

In all but the most simple of games, the complete consequences from actions performed are difficult to understand, but <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> can aid in understanding them. Actions may be tested for this reason simply because they have not been tested before if a player is willing to see a game session primarily as a learning period, but in other cases they may be necessary to do in all game sessions. Some games explicitly build <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> into gameplay as puzzles. In these cases, the actions used to test possible solutions are usually reversible.
Linderoth points out that actions in games are either exploratory or performatory, where the former can be seen as a form of Experimenting.

Gameplay in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mastermind">Mastermind</link></style> consists of one player guessing the correct combination of colored pegs. As the chance for guessing correctly based only on luck is very small, successful gameplay requires that the player combines the results from different guesses to draw conclusions and uses the guesses as experiments. The abstract game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zendo">Zendo</link></style> require players to set up arrangements of different colored pyramids to extrapolate the correct arrangement rules that a game master has decided to use for that particular game instance. Puzzle-solving in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sokoban">Sokoban</link></style> can take the form of <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> since failures only require players to replay levels.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Incredible%20Machine%20game%20series">Incredible Machine game series</link></style> lets players use a limit set of objects such as pipes, bowling balls, cats, candles, ropes, and balloons to try to reach goal states by making the objects interact with each other in certain ways. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pontifex">Pontifex</link></style>, players' goals are to build bridges and to learn how the physics model works. The players' have to experiment with how cable, joints, and metal beams interact.

Creating potions in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20III:%20Morrowind">The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind</link></style> can require <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> if players are not alchemist masters, as not all effects of ingredients are known until one reaches that skill level.

<style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> can rely on the presence of <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> goals so that players try to reach these goals by performing different variations of actions in a game, but this is not always enough since harsh <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> for failure may make players cautious. <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> can either by itself or in combination with <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> make players engage in <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> since a trial by error method may be the easiest (and possibly best) way of learning about how the game system works.

When <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals lie behind the need for <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style>, it also implies a presence of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> can be about the fundamental rules of cause and effect in computer games, about the long-term consequences of actions, or about the game state. For the first two cases, being able to do <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> or combining <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Foresight">Limited Foresight</link></style> is necessary for <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> to be worthwhile, while for the last case <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> can be supported by offering to possibility of gaining information about other players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technology%20Trees">Technology Trees</link></style>, etc. <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> is related to <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> in that the activity can be seen as wanting to find the right actions to perform. However, since testing this affects the game state games need to support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Reversibility">Reversibility</link></style> if the games overall should promote <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style>. A specific type of <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> required in games with <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> can be to figure out their <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> or other types of <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style>. While the need for <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> can make the presence of <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> counterproductive for <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style>, it can also make it required to experiment to figure out the nature of game environment (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style> requires this to figure out the effects of scrolls, potions, and rings).

<style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> goals that are to support <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> have similar requirements as those for <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals but here it may also be that players need to experiment as part of learning their skills. However, the need for <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> can be mechanically encouraged by <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> - either because they are part of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hidden%20Rules">Hidden Rules</link></style> (something sometimes done in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Fighting%20Games">Fighting Games</link></style>) or to identify emergent effects of <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> puts players in situations where the effect of every action can have the potential of affecting the overall outcome, and this may work against players' willingness to experiment. This can be compensated by making the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competitions</link></style> contain <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Red%20Queen%20Dilemmas">Red Queen Dilemmas</link></style>. Severe consequences of <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> may not be a problem in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quick%20Games">Quick Games</link></style> as long as they have no <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>, as a new game session can be started again. In <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, problematic consequences can be avoided by having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Reversibility">Reversibility</link></style> or supporting <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> can work against players considering alternatives, but can also force players to try something simple because they are running out of time.

Actions that are closely related to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Constructive%20Gameplay">Constructive Gameplay</link></style>, for example <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, are often better suited to support <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> than other actions because they are less likely to result in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style>. Specific design solutions to encourage <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> in a more general fashion include <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style> (players can experiment without feeling threatened), <style="Link"><link="arithmetic-progression">Arithmetic Progression</link></style> (erroneous efforts have limited consequences), and <style="Link"><link="testing-achievements">Testing Achievements</link></style> (players are given these <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style> as rewards for simply <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style>). The possibility to have <style="Link"><link="save-files">Save Files</link></style> also encourages <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> since players can rely on being able to go back to previous game states before initiating potentially riskily gameplay actions.

While the exploratory actions in games described by Linderoth can be seen as Experimenting, some patterns can work against this since they remove the need for players to do these actions. Examples of this include Point of Interest Indicators, Vision Modes, or Geospatial Game Widgets used for highlighting game objects or otherwise pointing out important game entities for players.

The act of planning and <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> promotes <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cognitive%20Engrossment">Cognitive Engrossment</link></style> in games, and both <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual</link></style>  and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> can be modulated by how costly it is to do <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style>. When <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> can have severe or costly consequences, they create <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and can require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style> but also encourage <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, especially if <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style> need to be used for the <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style>. As the actions performed when <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> do not usually fulfill a goal in the game, the activity gives <style="Link"><link="illusionary-rewards">Illusionary Rewards</link></style>, but these can be valuable for gameplay since they may let players discover the <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> which is possible to acquire and can thereby let players acquire <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> over time.

The possibility of testing various ways of performing actions and trying to reach goals in games makes <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>. Related to this, <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style> in a game can aid in avoiding <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style>, as players can try the effects and consequences of their ideas and plans rather than try to deduce the effects and consequences.
Rather obviously, <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> work against making players engage in <style="CurrentLink">Experimenting</style>.
